title: My 341 meeting has been continued twice
question: At the second meeting, the trustee said that he did not think it was legal for me to file in the northern District when I reside in southern CA. The trustee asked me to speak with someone at the US Trustee's office. The person at the US Trustee's office asked me a few a questions and then said it was okay to keep my file in the northern district bankruptcy court. The question she asked were:
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,341 meeting of creditors,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Debt,Unsecured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan
answers:
The trustee was probably questioning you because you live in one district, but filed in another. There is only one place that you can file - the place where you lived or had your primary assets within the majority of the 180 days before filing.

Chapter 13 after a 7 is known as a Chapter 20. You need to consult with counsel to find out if this your court will accept it. You may be better of converting the existing case or taking some other alternative.

Talk to a local attorney before deciding.

You really need to get some assistance from an attorney, it does not make sense to do a 13 after the 7.

The trustee was likely trying to determine if in fact the northern District would have jurisdiction over your case. Jurisdiction is based on where the filer resides or is domiciled (where you live). In your case, I think, after hearing you would be back in the northern District at the time of filing she believes that the Court there would have jurisdiction and proceed with the 341.

The question concerning your house was probably her just making clear that Chapter 7 bankruptcies only discharge unsecured debt and your house would not be saved simply by filing the 7.
